text_run.content: Principles of perceptual organization. The brain automatically groups elements. Key laws include:
Things that look alike seem grouped.
We see complete shapes even if parts are missing.
Things in the same boundary are grouped.
We follow smooth, continuous lines or curves.
Things moving in the same direction are grouped.
A core design principle. It means making the system's state and possible actions obvious. The goal is to put knowledge "in the world," not "in the head".
an agent to do. It's a relationship between the object and the user's capabilities.
the affordance (the action) can take place. Signifiers are often more important for designers than affordances.
A user's mental understanding of how a system works. The designer's goal is to ensure their
Core Principle: User Errors are Design Errors
The main message of the course is that we tend to blame users for mistakes, but usually, the product or UI design is to blame.

Rules developed by the "Berliner Schule" (K√∂hler, Koffka, Wertheimer) that describe how humans spatially or temporally perceive items as a group Ëß£Èáä‰∫∫Á±ªÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂ∞ÜËßÜËßâÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁªÑÁªáÊàêÊï¥‰Ωì. They are simple rules for good UI design.

Objects near each other are perceived as a group.
This allows for order by position only.
Closed lines appear as shapes and thus as belonging together. Â§ßËÑë‰ºöËá™Âä®Êää‰∏çÂÆåÊï¥ÁöÑÂõæÂΩ¢Ë°•ÊàêÂÆåÊï¥ÁöÑÂΩ¢Áä∂„ÄÇ
This is a foundation of the "window metaphor".
area (region) appear to belong together. (Note: The slides warn "Don't overdo it" .ËøáÂ∫¶‰ΩøÁî®
Similar shapes (or colors, sizes) appear as belonging together.
Also known as the "Law of the Good Curve". Continuous shapes appear as belonging together.
We tend to file new things into categories we already know.
This saves learning effort and is the foundation for metaphors (like the desktop metaphor).
Also "Law of Common Movement". Animated objects moving together (synchronously) within a static environment appear as a group.
The basic unit of information is the
, where N is the number of states.
Good for quick estimates, seeing trends, and viewing range limits.
Good for precise reading (reading time is constant up to 3-4 digits). ËØª 3‚Äì4 ‰ΩçÊï∞Â≠óÊó∂Èó¥Âá†‰πéÊÅíÂÆö
Much everyday knowledge is "in the world, not in the head".
Aims to make natural clues visible, requiring no conscious thought.
"Just the right things have to be visible." Too many clues are as bad as too few.
Can cause "false causalities" (thinking your action had no effect) and superstition (e.g., multiple clicks).

Affordances can be visible or hidden.
the action can take place. They are crucial if the affordance is not perceivable. ÂëäËØâÁî®Êà∑
Can be intentional (a "PUSH" sign) or unintentional (footprints in snow) .
Suggests an action that is not possible.üëâ
An unintended affordance (e.g., a railing that affords sitting).üëâ
A signifier that suggests the wrong action (e.g., a flat plate that implies "push" has a "PULL" label).
Humans form a conceptual (mental) model of how something works when they encounter it. A good model allows users to predict the effects of their actions.
